raw_text: For this task, we use a named entity recognizer (Isozaki and Kazawa, 2002)
clean_text: For this task, we use a named entity recognizer (Isozaki and Kazawa, 2002).

raw_text: Discriminative classifiers, which directly model the posterior distribution of class label given features ,i.e. SVM (Isozaki and Kazawa 2002) and Maximum Entropy model for NER (Chieu and Ng 2003), have been shown to outperform generative model based classifiers
clean_text: Discriminative classifiers, which directly model the posterior distribution of class label given features, i.e. SVM (Isozaki and Kazawa 2002) and Maximum Entropy model for NER (Chieu and Ng 2003), have been shown to outperform generative model based classifiers.

raw_text: Several approaches used classifiers such as decision trees or SVMs (Isozaki and Kazawa, 2002)
clean_text: Several approaches used classifiers such as decision trees or SVMs (Isozaki and Kazawa, 2002).

raw_text: Isozaki and Kazawa (2002) compared three commonly used methods for named entity recognition? the SVM with quadratic kernel, maximal entropy method, and a rule based learning system, and showed that the SVM-based system per formed better than the other two
clean_text: Isozaki and Kazawa (2002) compared three commonly used methods for named entity recognition the SVM with quadratic kernel, maximal entropy method, and a rule based learning system, and showed that the SVM-based system performed better than the other two.

This approach obviously does not scale well, both to tasks with more features and to larger degree kernels. PKE Heuristic Kernel Expansion, was introduced by (Kudo and Matsumoto, 2003).

raw_text: Support vector machines (e.g., Vapnik (1995), Joachims (1998)) are a different kind of kernel method that, unlike KPCA methods, have al ready gained high popularity for NLP applications (e.g., Takamura and Matsumoto (2001), Isozaki and Kazawa (2002), Mayfield et al (2003)) including the word sense disambiguation task (e.g., Cabezas et al (2001))

raw_text: Isozaki et al propose an XQK (eXpand the Quadratic Kernel) which can make their Named-Entity recognizer drastically fast (Isozaki and Kazawa, 2002)

citing_paper_authors: Elena, Lloret | Horacio, Saggion | Manuel, Palomar
raw_text: For the experiments reported here, we adopt a Sup port Vector Machine (SVM) learning paradigm not only because it has recently been used with success in different tasks in natural language processing (Isozaki and Kazawa, 2002), but it has been shown particularly suitable for text categorization (Kumar and Gopal, 2009) where the feature space is huge ,asit is in our case
clean_text: For the experiments reported here, we adopt a Support Vector Machine (SVM) learning paradigm not only because it has recently been used with success in different tasks in natural language processing (Isozaki and Kazawa, 2002), but it has been shown particularly suitable for text categorization (Kumar and Gopal, 2009) where the feature space is huge, as it is in our case.
